title: How many deaths attributed to COVID-19 in the US will be reported for the week ending 5 June﻿ 2021?
preds:
Numbers jumping up and down, seems impossible to predict  between <3000 and >3000 (quite  a deja-vu in forecasting this one). Date/ Day / Last week	/ This week	/ % of day last week
30.05.21	Sun	  191	124	  65%
31.05.21	Mon  429	142	  33%
01.06.21	Tue   620	638	103%
02.06.21	Wed  961	610	  63%
03.06.21	Thu	1338	601	  45%
04.06.21	Fri	  567	567	  100%
05.06.21	Sat	  343	?         ?
If the number for June 5 >=318 (93% of last week/May 29), it will be >3000k.

Preview of June 4 deaths: approximately 603. Deaths for June 5 would need to be ~450 for the total for the week to be <3000. Not likely.
I will have a horrible Brier score on this one!

I have been consistently estimating the max. reaching no higher than 3,100-3,200, but my minimum progressively slid from 2,100 all the way up to 2,900. 
It now looks like it will go to the wire; I’m expecting the final two days to average 15-20% lower than mid-week, with the total coming in at...
2,960-3,100
Is there a prize for getting within 50? :-)
Looking at it from another angle, I think it actually has a decent chance of staying under 3k.

Revising up a little bit, because it's still possible, if not likely. Total for the week so far at 2082, with 2 more days to go. The average for the week may still fall, though, and we may well see <3000.
I still don't understand why the CFR went down to about 1.0% but is now going back up substantially in the direction of 1.7%, where it was without vaccines. I can understand it *being* somewhat close to 1.7%; if nearly all of the people who are dying are not vaccinated, and they are skewed slightly younger than the rest of the population, then you'd expect the CFR to be <1.7%, and the age structure of the unvaccinated population will explain nearly all of the CFR. But I don't understand the CFR *going* pretty far down and then *going* back up. I guess one explanation could simply be that testing rates are going down; I haven't looked at that data.

Are the numbers imploding?
May 30 to June 3: 2082  deaths = 59% of May 23-27 (3539 back then). 
59% of entire last week (May 23 to 29) = .59 * 4453 = 2617
Even if the numbers for the last remaining days (June 4 and 5) are as high as last week (May 28 + May 29 the count was 910) – which I am not expecting – we’ll stay under 3000k (2082 + 910 = 2992).
Taking a very sharp turn to 95% for <3000
Revised best guess is 3.2k, but dropping because close call and I overestimated.

Seeing a hint that June 3's number is ~600, keeping deaths under 3000 for the week looks very unlikely at this point. Sunday and Monday are typically the lowest days of the week, so it doesn't seem reasonable to expect that the next 2 days (Friday and Saturday) will be under ~450. Still, it's not impossible.

My rational head has accepted that it’s more likely to be just over, rather than just under. The low numbers at the start of the week push down the average needed for the remaining days, but it’s by no means clear cut.  I’m humbly reverting to the middle ground and expecting 2,900-3,150

I can't make up my mind. <3000 still looks very possible to me. Need to let the data settle down after the holiday weekend.
Based on averaging deaths for the last 3 days reported to date, we're at 2114 deaths for the week. I don't expect it to stay this low, but I also don't expect the CFR to stay at ~1.5%.
I am starting to think we'll end up seeing just barely over 3000.

May 30 to June 1: 905 deaths = 73% of May 23-25 (1240 back then).
73% of entire last week (May 23 to 29) = .73*4453=3250
+1 to bin #4 in case of noisy spike up.

Looks like the variations tend to go upward and come back down to normal. And it jumps generally on WED, THU, FRIs. With this logic, I increase probability. Consistent with flattening trend overall and possibility that cases "spike" to whatever degree which will slow the rate of decline. New forecast just below my highest forecast by a degree. Pre-mortem: I could be undervaluing the decline and confusing the dynamics of/between confirmed cases and deaths - which I admit I do not particularly understand. My confidence is in my fellow forecasters, the graph trend, and the different what-ifs I posed. Pre-mortem: I used reasonable what-if scenarios and reasonable may be excluding fat tail events. Best bet for now, though, is bin #3. My lowest probability I would give bin #3 is upper 60s.

A bunch of states didn't update on memorial day which explains the drop in cases and deaths yesterday. Switching to favor over 3k again since the next day or two will probably make up for it. https://github.com/CSSEGISandData/COVID-19/issues/4166
Looks like a big drop yesterday. I think once the Oklahoma and Maryland retroactive deaths fall out of the weekly numbers this could be down below 3k.

Coming down due to sharp drop in cases over the past few days and fact that no state is currently above 1.00 infection rate. However, even if the national infection rate improves to the value of the top 30% best performing states, it is still just under 3.1k by 05 June. I.e., R-naught from 0.83 to 0.76. Thinking reasonable high end is 4.4k, reasonable low end 3.0k. A geo mean of somewhere around 3.65k. Because of falling rates, maybe the result will be below 3.65k, perhaps 3.3k. In spite, my best guess is between this mean and 4k.

Deaths are declining again, after a brief increase. However, it's not completely clear yet whether the decline is due to decreased holiday reporting. But I suspect deaths will continue to fall, in line with cases 3 weeks ago and Covid ICU occupancy 1 week ago.

Back to 50:50
May 30 was 65% of May 23. If the other six days will be 65% of last week, we will get....3004.
I don't understand why there is an uptick in deaths right now. My best guess is stochastic variation in times to deaths and/or age composition of Covid ICU patients. We'll see.

It's petering out as supported by the models. Lots of room in Bin 3 if things improve. Things worsening would be a far fetch; all but one state is seeing a negative infection rate and the only state that is positive is at 1.06, which is not rather strong (assumption).
Assuming trend continues. I also factored in a reasonable scenario that saw an improvement in decline of 4%. Would have to improve 13% to reach 3k.
Listening to @cjh on this. We may not see deaths fall to <3k in the forecast period. It remains to be seen whether the spike of the past couple days will continue; I am guessing that it won't.

The recent spike looks like it's all coming from Maryland and Oklahoma. Can't find an article about Oklahoma but you can see it on their recent state graph on google. Maryland was counting of previous deaths per the article below, I assume Oklahoma is the same. Maryland article: https://www.baltimoresun.com/coronavirus/bs-md-covid-numbers-20210527-icecj6mj6rc2bjld7b7vc7i2xq-story.html Google sheet I used to figure out where the anomalies were coming from: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1IasstVuKweNEUfPwSMUfJPIEMpGOOyMxESsz-Texk3w/edit?usp=sharing They should drop off the weekly deaths by June 5 barring some other reporting, which is why I'm leaving 2% in 4,500 to 6,000. Switching to favor about 3,000 now, I think the decline in weekly deaths looks like it's finally started to increase a bit to better match the decline in cases, but there's not much time left and I'm not sure it can make it to under 3k.
4662 deaths in sum May 21 to May 27, that's a surprise...just outliers?

I'm no longer convinced the death rate will fall quickly enough to get sub-3,000 for the week, given the limited time left.
I had expected no higher than 2,900 in total, but the rate has only started to drop as forecast in the last few days, which has left a substantially bigger gap to cross.
Currently expecting around 3,200, but still hoping they are able to reduce numbers rapidly from here on.
Trajectory suggest that it will be close to 3000, but likely a bit above.

The CDC policy change on may 1 is significant here. Going forward, anyone who is vaccinated is tested differently than anyone who is not vaccinated. For someone who has been vaccinated you will only be considered as being positive for covid-19 if your test cycles are less than or equal to 28, but for anyone not vaccinated they will still be counting tests with cycles above 28. They are also counting deaths among people who are vaccinated differently than among people who are not vaccinated. With 30% of the general population vaccinated, and more importantly 70% of the elderly vaccinated this is a significant policy change that will affect this question. As the CDC website states, some state health departments may not follow this guidance. Which follows that they expect some state heath departments to follow the policy. Of course, some states don't even track the test cycles of the tests they use, but many do.
https://off-guardian.org/2021/05/18/how-the-cdc-is-manipulating-data-to-prop-up-vaccine-effectiveness/
Deaths per week is declining slowly. It’s looking likely to stay above 3000 now.

I still think they can just scrape in under 3,000 for the week, but it does look increasingly close
Expecting a sharper drop over the next 7 days

Expecting deaths per day to average 300 people that week (not far from that number today). The cumulative number of vaccinations will be somewhat higher and summer is approaching. The only reason I would expect the daily average to increase would be if more infectious variants outcompeted the currently dominant virus, or if CDC guidance was abused. If we see the rate of first-dose vaccinations go up, then I would expect this number to improve.

Only dropped about 700 in the last two weeks, and 700 more would put it at 3,300. I expected it to fall faster to match the decline in cases by now so I'm adding more weight to the 3k to 4.5k bucket. Possible the lag is just a little longer for whatever reason and we'll still see deaths begin to decline more rapidly. If we don't see that over the next week I'll switch to favoring 3k to 4.5k.

Deaths have always been stickier than cases and here, it seems that the collective forecast is a bit too aggressive. At the moment,  US is clocking ~4200 deaths/rolling week and the Covid ICU beds have hovered between 9k -10k for much of Apr and May.
I'd expected the death rate to fall by approx 60-65/wk (7-day av.) by this point - there is still time, but it is looking increasingly close to the 3,000 mark

Update. Deaths for the week ending June 5 = cases for the week ending May 15 * 7-day average case fatality rate (CFR) on June 5. On the JHU webpage today for cases in the past week, ending May 15: 237,017. This will likely be revised slightly upward, to perhaps about 240k. 
Then the 7-day average of cases/day on May 15 = 237k/7 to 240k/7 = 33.9k to 34.3k. 7-day CFR on June 5 = 7-day average of deaths/day on June 5 / 7-day average of cases/day on May 15. The 7-day CFR has been declining since vaccination started, but the pace of the decline has slowed recently. The 7-day CFR may now have plateaued around 1.00% +/- fluctuations as large as 0.05%. It's possible that it may continue to decline further, but clearly at a pace slower than its previous 0.1%/10 days, as vaccination rates have slowed. It could also start to increase a bit as many people stop wearing masks indoors, thereby increasing the exposure of vulnerable people, both vaccinated and unvaccinated, to the virus, but such an effect wouldn't be seen until after the forecast period, because any such people are only now just starting to get sick. The most recent values of the 7-day CFR were 1.02%, 1.02%, 1.00%, 1.00%; over the past 28 days, values have ranged from 0.95% to 1.16%. Thus, I think it's extremely likely that the 7-day CFR could reach 1.26%, as that would require a faster increase over the next 21 days than the decline observed over the past 28 days and is not plausible. On June 5, I think the 7-day CFR will likely be in the range ~0.9% to ~1.1%, tending towards lower or higher values depending on whether vaccinations or the effects of behavioral complacency predominate, respectively. For deaths to be <1500, the 7-day CFR on June 5 would need to be <= ~0.63%. I don't think there's any chance of that happening.
For deaths to be >3000, the 7-day CFR on June 5 would need to be >= ~1.26%. I also don't think there's any chance of that happening.
Thus, I believe there is now a 100% chance that deaths will be in the second forecast bin. Update 5/20: Still forecasting bin 2. The 7-day CFR has been bouncing around a bit; I wonder whether the numbers are just getting so small that we're seeing more noise. Whatever the reason, I still expect bin 2 because the unvaccinated population and hence the infected population is skewed towards those at less risk of death.
Looked further at the data. Looks like case rates dropped 34% 21 days ago, which is predictive for deaths rates the week of June 7th.  So that large a drop is possible.
We are under 4500 now, and the rate is dropping. But we are unlikely to see a 34% drop in 3 weeks.

Giving 25% to 3000+ again, for three reasons:
1)	Daily decline in weekly sum of deaths is only 1.0% - project this onto June 5: 3455 deaths
2)	https://viz.covid19forecasthub.org/ ensemble remains clearly over 3000
3)	@belikewater “CFR” (deaths p.week / new cases p. weeks 21 days earlier) is going up:  1.04% yesterday (May 14) which is 0.1 points more than May 11; there seems to be some “viscosity” in the death toll as ftalities apparently are driven by not just by the cases a few weeks earlier (they may include, for instance, parts of the population refusing to test until they are in a hospital /morgue requiring it). 
On May 15 (three weeks before June 5) there will be roughly 240000 cases. If the “CFR” rises to 1.25%+ (which it would if it keeps on increasing like in the past three days) , there will be more than 3000 deaths.

Update 5/11. Deaths for the week ending June 5 = 7 * 7-day average cases/day on May 15 * 7-day average case fatality rate (CFR) on June 5. 
Current linear projection for 7-day average of cases/day on May 15: 32.8k. This is about 0.3k to 0.4k lower than my earlier forecasts.
7-day CFR on June 5 = 7-day average of deaths/day on June 5 / 7-day average of cases/day on May 15. 
7-day CFR on June 5 will be between 0.0067 and 0.0010 (extreme upper bound, very unlikely). 
Then total deaths for week ending June 5 in different scenarios: 
7 * 32.8k * 0.0067 = 1538
7 * 32.8k * 0.0010 = 2296
These numbers are based on nytimes data. JHU numbers are running very slightly lower. JHU deaths are 97% to 98% of nytimes deaths. Probably JHU data will be increased later after back reporting; nytimes data are cases and deaths reported *on* those days; I think JHU data are cases and deaths reported *for* those days. 
But just in case, the best lower bound is 0.97 * 1538 = 1492, very close to the bin limit. But a 7-day CFR of 0.0067 is very unlikely; 7-day CFR will likely be closer to 0.008.

There are some really good rationales on this one, but I still feel the CFR will not track much lower in the time frame and will tend to flatten during this steady drop in cases. So the first bin still looks unrealistic to me, but equally I can't see the numbers getting above 2,900 at this point. 
@CJH I'm also expecting 205-220K cases, but correlating to over 2,000 deaths total. The next week of data will certainly be interesting :-)

Getting much closer to @belikewater ‘s projection (should have done this earlier!)
CFR (deaths / cases 3 weeks earlier) now decreasing by 0.05% per week, on May 10 CFR was 0.95%, guess it will be around .75 to .80% at the beginning of June.
Expect 180-230k cases  three weeks before June 5, with a CFR of 0.75% it would mean 1350-1725 deaths.
Surprised about the high numbers in the ensemble forecast but tending to ignore them now.

Going by a three week lag between cases and deaths, three weeks ago on April 20 weekly cases were at 453k and today they're at 271k. Deaths today are at 4,443. So cases dropped to 60% of what they were over the three weeks and I expect the same to happen with deaths over the next three weeks, which would put it around 2,665 deaths on June 1st. Based on that I'm switching to favor the 1,500 to 3,000 bucket. As a pre-mortem, a reason I could be wrong is that vaccine prevalence may have decoupled deaths from cases to some extent, so previous patterns may not hold. That could mean there's some possibility that we won't see as large of a reduction in deaths as expected (maybe the virus is primarily circulating in an unhealthy unvaccinated population now for example) or it could mean we see a greater reduction (reduction due to fewer cases but also due to cases being less deadly due to vaccine protection).

Running at 650 per day with slight decrease.  650 per day gives 4,550 per week
Threshold for 3k is 420 per day.  That feels too far of a drop

Update 5/11. Deaths for the week ending June 5 = 7 * 7-day average cases/day on May 15 * 7-day average case fatality rate (CFR) on June 5.
Current linear projection for 7-day average of cases/day on May 15: 33.1k. The forecast has been stable around 33.1k to 33.2k for the past several days.
7-day CFR on June 5 = 7-day average of deaths/day on June 5 / 7-day average of cases/day on May 15.
7-day CFR on June 5 will be between 0.0067 and 0.0010 (extreme upper bound, very unlikely).
Then total deaths for week ending June 5 in different scenarios: 
7 * 33.1k * 0.0067 = 1552
7 * 33.1k * 0.0010 = 2317
These numbers are based on nytimes data. JHU numbers are running very slightly lower. JHU deaths are 97% to 98% of nytimes deaths. Probably JHU data will be increased later after back reporting; nytimes data are cases and deaths reported *on* those days; I think JHU data are cases and deaths reported *for* those days.
But just in case, the best lower bound is 0.97 * 1552 = 1505, very close to the bin limit. But a 7-day CFR of 0.0067 is very unlikely; 7-day CFR will likely be closer to 0.008.

Update. Deaths for the week ending June 5 = 7 * 7-day average cases on May 15 * 7-day average CFR on June 5.
Current linear projection (R^2 = 0.995, it's a nearly perfect line) for 7-day average of cases/day on May 15: 33.2k. So far, this prediction has been 1) 32.2k, 2) 32.6k, 3) 32.9k, 4) 33.1k, 5) 33.1k, 6) 33.2k. 6 more days to go. With back reporting and a slow trend upward, this number could end up being 33.2k-33.5k.
I had forecasted that the 7-day CFR would likely be 0.68% +/- 0.03% on June 5 or perhaps a little higher if the decline in the 7-day CFR slows down. Well, the decline does seem to be slowing down. So for now, until I have a clearer picture, I'm going to shift to 0.69% +/- 0.03% (out of caution around the lower boundary of the forecast bin), but it'll probably be higher. Previously, the 7-day CFR was declining by 0.1% every ~10 days; perhaps it'll stretch out to ~15 days? If it stretched out to 0.1%/15 days, then the 7-day CFR would be just under 0.8%. But as a worst-case scenario, today's value (0.99%) would be a ceiling, as I can't imagine the 7-day CFR increasing over the forecast period.
Then total deaths for week ending June 5 in different scenarios:
7 * 33.2k * 0.0069 = 1604
7 * 33.2k * 0.0066 = 1534, a lower bound
7 * 33.2k * 0.0072 = 1673
7 * 33.5k * 0.0073 = 1712
7 * 33.7k * 0.0099 = 2335, if we use an extremely high May 15 case forecast and today's CFR, an extreme upper bound.
Overall, the bottom of range for the forecast is very close to 1500, so the forecast should be watched closely, but the upper limit is well under 3000. For further details: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1273759 P.S. I'm using numbers from nytimes.com for convenience. (Google "us covid cases", and the graph comes up, at least where I am.) However, JHU cases are inevitably going to be slightly different. On their website, their 7-day average cases/day for the past week is 184 = 0.2k smaller than the nytimes number. They will also increase case counts over time with back reporting. But suppose their number ends up being 0.2k smaller than the nytimes number. Then the total JHU deaths for the week could be slightly lower, realistically no lower than 7 * 33.0k * 0.007 = 1617, still firmly in bin 2. On the other hand, their total deaths for the past week were 142 lower than the nytimes deaths, but again, those will probably be adjusted up as additional reports come in. But there is *some* chance that the forecast will land in bin 1.
Deaths have dropped circa 30% over the last month. Deaths lag behind cases what are currently falling rapidly.

I need a rationale for this one as I seem to be flying against the wind. I have tried a few approaches but still come out with an approx range 2,400-3,100, which is clearly off from the crowd. 
As we have ground through the pandemic the ratio between case numbers and deaths has gradually changed. Expertise and treatments have become more effective at preventing deaths over time, particularly in countries with more robust heath systems, and especially so now in countries with widespread vaccine distribution. In the US from mid-March to Mid-April for example, the rolling 7-day av. case rate increased from a low of 55K to a high of 72K, but in the related period (allowing for ~15day lag of course)  the number of deaths dropped 15%. So with case numbers declining it seems fair to assume that the death rate will drop at least as quickly in relative terms. And this does look to be borne out when comparing with other countries in similar circumstances. 
Since cases peaked in mid-April, the numbers have steadily dropped 40%, but this has only just started to be reflected in death rates over the last week or so. Even if case numbers don't continue to track downwards, I see the rate of death falling more quickly from this week on, between 9-12% per week. 
Until new information comes in, I'm keeping to a forecast range 2,100-3,100, and expecting around 2,650 total.

I think the 7-day average of cases/day on May 15 will likely be >= 33.1k.
Current projection (R^2 = 0.995): 33.1k 7-day average of cases/day on May 15. So far, this prediction has been 1) 32.2k, 2) 32.6k, 3) 32.9k, 4) 33.1k, 5) 33.1k. 7 more days to go. With back reporting, it could be a little more than 33.1k.
The 7-day CFR is still on track to be 0.68 on June 5, leaning towards a possibility of being greater than that rather than less than that, and in the range 0.065 to 0.071.
Then total deaths for week ending June 5:
7-day CFR on June 5, total deaths
0.0068, 33.1k * 0.0068 * 7 = 1576, today's best estimate
0.0065, 33.1k * 0.0065 * 7 = 1506, today's lower bound
0.0071, 33.1k * 0.0071 * 7 = 1645, today's upper bound
Still very close to 1500, the line between bins, so the forecast should be watched closely. For further details: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1273759

Interesting relationship between cases and deaths (with approx 15 days lag in peak levels between the two) now we are back to declining case numbers
Forecast 2,400-2,650, with est. potential range 2,100-3,100

Update. Cases are continuing to decline very slightly more slowly than my linear forecast. Current projection (R^2 = 0.995): 33.1k 7-day average of cases/day on May 15. So far, this prediction has been 1) 32.2k, 2) 32.6k, 3) 32.9k, 4) 33.1k. 8 more days to go. Will it end up around 35k? Based on the last 4 days alone, it could also be 31.8k.
The 7-day CFR is still on track to be 0.68 on June 5.
Then total deaths for week ending June 5:
7-day CFR on June 5, total deaths
0.0068, 33.1k * 0.0068 * 7 = 1576, today's best estimate
0.0065, 33.1k * 0.0065 * 7 = 1506, today's lower bound
0.0071, 33.1k * 0.0071 * 7 = 1645, today's upper bound
0.0065, 32.2k * 0.0065 * 7 = 1465, using lowest case projection so far and lowest 7-day CFR = current lower bound
0.0068, 35k * 0.0068 * 7 = 1666, projecting cases to May 15, best projected estimate?
0.0065, 35k * 0.0065 * 7 = 1593, projecting cases to May 15, one possible lower bound
0.0071, 35k * 0.0071 * 7 = 1740, projecting cases to May 15, best projected upper bound?
0.0065, 31.8k * 0.0065 * 7 = 1447, projecting cases to May 15 based only on the past 4 days, a better lower bound? So, today's prediction is for just over 1,500 deaths in the forecast period, and somewhere in the range from 1,447 to 1,740 deaths, slightly more into the 2nd bin. Cases continue to decline more slowly than each day's linear forecast for 3 days in a row now, but time will tell. Cases could equally end up under 32k. For further details: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1273759 Update 5/9: Today's forecast is exactly the same. 31.1k cases/day 7-day average on May 15, and 7-day CFR of 0.068.

Starting from linear decline estimates (see @belikewater) and
considering a more than linear (exponential?) decline, would lead to an even more
optimistic estimate.

Update. This forecast relies on cases continuing to decline, on a linear forecast downward in the 7-day average of cases/day through May 15 (9 more days of data), and on a linear projection for a continuing decline in the case fatality rate (CFR) through June 5. Cases: Linearly projecting 7-day average cases/day from April 14 forward to May 15 (3 weeks before June 5; R^2 = 0.995), the 7-day average of cases/day on May 15 will be ~32.9k/day. So far, this prediction has been 1) 32.2k, 2) 32.6k, 3) 32.9k, so there is some variability in this forecast, and it's possible that cases are slowing ever so slightly more slowly than linearly. Need to watch this carefully. CFR: 3 week lag in deaths after cases. Before vaccinations, deaths were 1.7% of cases diagnosed 3 weeks before. Now, the 7-day average of deaths/day is 1.0% of the 7-day average of cases/day 3 weeks ago and has been at 1.0% for the past 7 days; I'll call this the "7-day CFR." The 7-day CFR was 1.1% for 10 days, from April 20 to 29. There are 30 forecast days left. Projecting linearly and allowing 10 days per 0.1% reduction in the CFR (i.e., 0.01%/day), the 7-day CFR will be 0.7% or possibly as low as 0.6% by June 5. An excessively precise forecast is 0.68% => 0.0068 +/- 0.00013 (std dev); the largest error in this forecast since 4/19 is 0.0003, which happened once. Unfortunately, this question's forecast will need that level of precision because it's right on the line between forecast bins. The downward trend in the 7-day CFR needs to be watched to see whether it slows down. Then total deaths for week ending June 5:
7-day CFR on June 5, total deaths
0.0068, 32.9k * 0.0068 * 7 = 1566, best current estimate
0.0065, 32.9k * 0.0065 * 7 = 1497, today's lower bound
0.0071, 32.9k * 0.0071 * 7 = 1635, today's upper bound, using highest case projection so far and highest 7-day CFR, today's upper bound = best upper bound
0.0068, 32.2k * 0.0068 * 7 = 1533, using lowest case projection so far, best lower bound
0.0065, 32.2k * 0.0065 * 7 = 1465, using lowest case projection so far and lowest 7-day CFR = current lower bound So, today's prediction is for just over 1,500 deaths in the forecast period, and somewhere in the range from 1,465 to 1,570 deaths. PS Whenever you get to it, @CJH, this question is the most "interesting" to forecast this time, imo, albeit for a sad topic.

Update: 
Linear forecast for case numbers for May 15: 32,600
R^2 for the fit: 0.996
CFR for yesterday (7-day deaths/7-day cases 3 weeks ago): 0.98
forecast 7-day CFR for June 5: 0.68
total forecast deaths: 32600 * 7 * 0.0068 = 1552

I am guessing that cases will continue to decline in the US because of seasonality and increasing vaccination rates. This forecast relies on that trend continuing, on a linear forecast downward in the 7-day average of cases/day through May 15 (11 more days of data), and on a linear projection for a continuing decline in the case fatality rate. Deaths today are from cases confirmed 3 weeks ago (on average). Before vaccinations, deaths were 1.7% of cases 3 weeks previously. Now, the 7-day average of deaths/day is 1.0% of the 7-day average of cases/day 3 weeks ago and has been at 1.0% for the past 5 days. The confirmed case fatality rate (CFR) was 1.1% for 10 days, from April 20 to 29. There are 32 forecast days left. Projecting linearly and allowing 10 days per 0.1% reduction in the CFR, the CFR may be 0.7% or possibly as low as 0.6% by June 5 (excessively precise forecast ~0.68%). To answer this question, it would be useful to project 7-day average cases/day forward to 3 weeks before June 5, or May 15. Linearly projecting cases from April 14 onward (R^2 = 0.984), the 7-day average of cases/day on May 15 will be ~32.2k/day. If the 7-day average of deaths/day on June 5 is 1.0% of the 7-day average of cases/day on May 15, then the 7-day average of deaths/day on June 5 would be ~32.2k * 0.010 = ~322. Then the total deaths for the week would be ~322 * 7 = ~2254. This is likely an upper bound, as the CFR will likely continue to fall. If deaths were 0.5% of cases, then the total would be ~32.2k * 0.005 = ~1125. This is likely a lower bound. If the 7-day average of deaths/day on June 5 is 0.7% of the 7-day average of cases/day on May 15, then the 7-day average deaths/day on June 5 would be ~32.2k * 0.007 = ~225, corresponding to 225 * 7 = 1,575 deaths in the week ending June 5. If CFR = 0.6%, then the 7-day average deaths/day on June 5 would be ~32.2k * 0.006 = ~193, corresponding to 1,350 deaths in the week ending June 5. To forecast to an excessive level of precision, if CFR = 0.68%, then deaths for the week would be 32,151 * .0068 * 7 = 1,530. So, my prediction is for just over 1,500 deaths in the forecast period, somewhere in the range from 1,350 to 1,575 deaths, and my subjective 95% confidence interval is about 1,125 to 2,254. The number likely wouldn't be as high as 2254, but it also likely wouldn't be as low as 1125. I will assign slightly more weight to the lower forecast bin. I will plan to watch the case numbers and CFR and update accordingly.

Very unlikely to increase again - current rate ~ 5000/week.
Deaths in June are due to infections one month in advance

Deaths have been steady around 700 per day for the last month
With cases holding steady/ slightly dropping there is no reason for this to drop dramatically over the next month.
700 per day is 4.9k per week so probably will be in a range 1k plus or minus around this.

A steady drop seems likely. The ensemble model is projecting 3,420 in four weeks, with a 95% confidence interval of 1,359 to 5,474. I agree with that, and I think comparing to Israel is useful where they've followed a steady drop, though ours has leveled out a little bit. I think it's likely to continue downward and probably at a faster pace once we get past the lag from the rise in cases a few weeks ago. But if it continues on the same trend as the last two weeks it would drop to around 3,900.
